description: From Middle English distraught, merger of distract (“distracted”) and straught (“stretched, distraught”), past participle of strecchen (“to stretch”). Compare also bestraught, extraught, forstraught, etc. More at distract, stretch.

adjectives.description: distraught (comparative more distraught, superlative most distraught)

entries.meaning: Deeply hurt, saddened, or worried; incapacitated by distress.
examples: His distraught widow cried for days, feeling very alone.
